By slowing the vehicles down, this arrangement allows for drivers to more easily find the appropriate lane for the next intersection.

status_notes: Case Noted. Thank you for bringing your concern about perceived speeding to our attention. Please know that federal criteria in the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices (MUTCD) prevents cities and towns from installing stop signs for speed control (Section 2B.04). Stop signs installed for speed control in the past have been found to be counterproductive, and have increased mid-block speeds between stop signs and reduced compliance at stop signs. BTD is currently in the process of implementing the Neighborhood Slow Streets program for traffic calming in two pilot areas. We are developing an application process so that other neighborhoods can benefit from traffic calming and reduced speeds on their streets. You can learn more about the program at visionzeroboston.org/nss. We suggest that you also add any additional concerns to our ?safety issues? map at the following link: app01.cityofboston.gov/VZSafety/. To get updates in your inbox, please join the mailing list at visionzeroboston.org/contact.

status_notes: Case Noted. Thank you for your interest in making our streets safer. The City of Boston recently opted in to adopt a lower default speed limit of 25 mph unless otherwise posted. Default speed limits are citywide, and are not posted on each block. However, we have installed several 25 mph signs at entry points to city streets, including one on northbound Brookline Ave near Fenwood Ave. The speed bumps and 20 mph speed limit proposed in Dorchester are part of the City’s Neighborhood Slow Streets initiative. We are developing an application process so that other neighborhoods can benefit from traffic calming. You can learn more about the program at visionzeroboston.org/nss. To get updates in your inbox, please join the mailing list at visionzeroboston.org/contact.

status_notes: Case Noted. Thank you for your feedback. We try to keep the detail field to 500 characters to make it easier for City of Boston staff to quickly and effectively respond to cases. If you feel your case requires longer explanation we always encourage constituents to email 311@boston.gov or call 311 to explain. Also we do allow you to send pictures through email to provide further context. If your case is a neighborhood specific request, you also might consider reaching out to your neighborhood liaison, Warren O'Reilly to explain your situation. His email is warren.oreilly@boston.gov. Thanks again for using Boston 311.

status_notes: Case Noted. This request will be evaluated as part of a Boston Transportation Department Traffic signal re-timing evaluation during FY18.
description: Southbound traffic on West Newton St frequently backs up at the intersection with Columbus Ave. The problem is that there is a single lane for cars turning either left or right at the intersection. Thus, a car that is waiting to turn left must wait for the right of way from oncoming traffic traveling northbound on West Newton St. before turning, preventing any traffic behind it that wishes to turn right from doing so, which causes the backup. A solution would be to create separate right and left turn lanes markings at the intersection so that right turning traffic can freely turn and avoid having to wait for left turn traffic to turn.  The space is already available for two turn lanes. Parking is prohibited on the southbound side of West Newton St from 8am-6pm. Permanent parking prohibition of only a few car lengths would be necessary to create a right turn lane. Please consider this improvement.
address: Intersection Of Columbus Ave & W Newton St, Roxbury

status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent. National Grid is installing a new main on your street. The city highly encourages this type of work. It will eliminate possible future emergency leak repairs. The city acknowledges that the construction will cause an inconvenience to the residents. However in the long run the construction is well worth it. Having a street dug up for emergency repairs soon after paving is frustrating for all. With the new gas main installed, the city can feel extremely comfortable that no embarrassing street cuts will happen if it determines to pave your street in the future. Even though the contactor will installing a new main usually for hundreds of feet and in some cases the entire street, we have told the contractor to only post where he will be for the next few days. This will allow more parking on the street. In addition Feeney Brothers is responsible for snow removal before work can resume. We spoke to the crew and told them they have to follow this requirement . They apologized and said they would comply going forward.  The sign is valid, in fact it tells you who the permiteee is and the contractor doing the work. We apologize for the inconvenience this necessary work will cause. For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The Boston Public Works Construction Inspection Unit (CIU) Inspector Verizon had an occupancy permit to pull cable at this location. description:
Re: case #1981374
Litter at 130 Newbury st...
Um it seems that this is somewhat irresponsible to let this pass as "acceptable" behavior in This Great City of Boston.

This kind of habit of slacking on such a very important issue of properly protecting our communities from disease carrying rodents etc, is truly everyone's duty and responsibility.
It is the responsibility of the businesses that serve our communities to maintain there spaces properly, inside and out, clean and free of garbage, trash and debris.
It is the responsibility of those we hire to deal with these issues to properly educate, explain and enforce these codes.
Especially when it comes to public health.
Look it's not rocket science,
If we truly want to get an issue in the rodent infestation in Boston right now, then we all have to bring our standards of common sense and common decency up a level or two.
Clearly in violation of Mass Sanitary Code
105 CMR: 410.600: (Storage of Rubbish and Garbage)- 
Rodent proof?

status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. As I stated over the phone with you, the paving condition of Blue Hill Ave is a top priority for the City. Before any paving can take place, the Public Works wants to make sure that any utility work needed is done first. Obviously that makes sense. The Public Works has built an online reservation system were everyone who wants to do construction work has to enter it into the database first. Conflicts are flagged and coordination can take place. This  helps eliminates embarrassing street cuts after a street has been paved. Since the creation of the online reservation system we have flagged over 10,000 conflicts, with a savings of over $30 Million dollars that would have been spent on repairing cuts on brand new roadways. Blue Hill Ave has had major utility work over the last few years, including new gas mains, which is a plus for the neighborhood. There is still more utility work planned for Blue Hill Ave. We have identified some of the utility work that does not meet our standards and requested that repairs be made. .  Some of the repairs have been done, and the remaining locations will be done shortly. Mayor Walsh understands how important dependable utility service is to our residents. He also understands that it is important we make sure the utilities follow our rules, and do a good job. . You can contact the number below sometime before the Spring and we can give you a definitive update on the sections of Blue Hill Ave we want to pave in 2017. For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

status_notes: Case Noted. The piles of rocks appear to have been created to provide beneficial habitat for fish to spawn. Although we have no record of specifically creating these piles of rocks in Jamaica Pond, people who have been with the department for a long time have confirmed that these rock formations have been there for years if not decades. Massachusetts Division of Fisheries & Wildlife has been contacted. They also did not have any record of creating them, they did confirm that they are definitely man made and provide good habitat for macroinverterbrates, juvenile fish, etc.  They do not recommend that the formations be removed. We have inspected the bank and there are no indications of significant erosion that need to be addressed at this time, and there are no obvious missing riprap along the bank at these formations (see photo). It is likely these were gathered together from the pond basin (which is where I'm told the riprap also came from). No action is needed at this time. If you have any questions, please contact the Parks Department's Design & Construction Division at 617-635-4505.  Thank you.
description: At Jamaica Pond someone mysteriously removed hundreds of rocks from the protective embankment to form piles of stones. These are ordinarily under water but in this drought are not. The city should take advantage of the low water to replace the stones to prevent erosion of the pond banks.
